column3: How to declare a pointer in C++?
column9: int *ptr; declares a pointer to an integer.
* is used to access the value at the address stored in a pointer.
& returns the memory address of a variable.

column3: What is a reference in C++?
column9: Reference is an alias (another name) for an existing variable.
int &ref = x; creates a reference ref to variable x.

column3: What is a class in C++?
column9: Class is a user-defined data type that serves as a blueprint for objects.
Object is an instance of a class.
Encapsulation is bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a class.

column4: Deriving new class from existing class
column9: Inheritance allows a new class to acquire properties of an existing class.
A
column10: Polymorphism allows objects of different types to be treated as objects of a common type.

column9: Abstraction shows only essential features and hides implementation details.
Constructor is a special member function that initializes objects of a class.
Destructor is a special member function that cleans up when an object is destroyed.

column4: Multiple functions with same name but different parameters
column9: Function overloading allows multiple functions with same name but different parameters.
Operator overloading allows defining new behaviors for C++ operators.
Templates allow writing generic code that works with different data types.
STL is a powerful set of C++ template classes providing common data structures and algorithms.

column3: What is a vector in C++?
column9: Vector is a dynamic array that can resize automatically.

column3: How to include vector in C++?
column9: #include <vector> includes the vector header file.

column3: What is a map in C++?
column9: Map stores elements as key-value pairs with unique keys.
Exception handling deals with runtime errors using try

column3: What is the try block used for?
column9: try block contains code that might throw exceptions.

column3: What is the catch block used for?
column9: catch block handles exceptions thrown in the try block.

column3: What is the throw keyword used for?
column9: throw keyword is used to raise an exception.
Namespace prevents naming conflicts by grouping identifiers.

column4: Brings std namespace into current scope
column9: using namespace std; makes all std namespace identifiers available without std:: prefix.

column3: What is the scope resolution operator?
column9: :: is used to access global variables or class members.
this is a pointer that points to the current object instance.

column4: Shared by all objects of class
column9: Static member is shared by all objects of the class.

column3: What is a const member function?
column9: const member function promises not to modify the object's state.

column4: Function that can access private members
column9: Friend function can access private and protected members of a class.
Virtual function enables runtime polymorphism and can be overridden in derived classes.

column3: What is a pure virtual function?
column4: Function with no implementation in base class
column9: Pure virtual function has no implementation in base class and makes class abstract.

column4: Class with at least one pure virtual function
column9: Abstract class cannot be instantiated and serves as a base class.

column3: What is the new operator used for?
column9: new allocates memory dynamically on the heap.

column3: What is the delete operator used for?
column9: delete frees memory allocated with new.
Memory leak occurs when dynamically allocated memory is not freed.
sizeof returns the size of a variable or type in bytes.
Type casting converts a variable from one data type to another.
dynamic_cast safely converts pointers/references in polymorphic class hierarchies.
static_cast performs conversions known at compile time.
const_cast adds or removes const qualifier from variables.
reinterpret_cast converts any pointer type to any other pointer type
Inline function suggests compiler to insert function code at call site to reduce overhead.
Default argument provides a default value if no argument is passed.

column4: Redefining base class function in derived class
column9: Function overriding redefines a base class virtual function in derived class.
override explicitly indicates that a function is intended to override a virtual function.
final prevents a virtual function from being overridden or a class from being inherited.
Lambda expression creates an anonymous function object.
auto deduces the type of a variable from its initializer.
nullptr represents a null pointer and is type-safe.

column4: Iterates over all elements of a container
column9: Range-based for loop simplifies iteration over containers.
Smart pointer automatically manages memory to prevent leaks.
unique_ptr has exclusive ownership and cannot be copied.
shared_ptr allows multiple pointers to share ownership of same object.

column4: Smart pointer that doesn't increase reference count
column9: weak_ptr is a non-owning smart pointer that references a shared_ptr managed object.
break immediately exits the loop or switch statement.

column4: Skips to next iteration of loop
column9: continue skips remaining code in current iteration and moves to next iteration.
goto transfers control to a labeled statement (generally avoided).
switch selects among multiple code blocks based on expression value.

column3: What is the case keyword in switch?
column9: case specifies a value to match in a switch statement.

column3: What is the default case in switch?
column9: default executes when none of the case values match.
? : is a shorthand for if-else that returns a value.
Comma operator allows multiple expressions where one is expected.
-> accesses members of an object through a pointer.
Bitwise operators perform operations on individual bits.

column3: What is the bitwise AND operator?
column9: & performs bitwise AND operation.

column3: What is the bitwise OR operator?
column9: | performs bitwise OR operation.

column3: What is the bitwise XOR operator?
column9: ^ performs bitwise XOR (exclusive OR) operation.

column3: What is the bitwise NOT operator?
column9: ~ performs bitwise NOT (complement) operation.

column3: What are left shift and right shift operators?
column9: << shifts bits left

column3: What is the logical AND operator?
column9: && performs logical AND operation.

column3: What is the logical OR operator?
column9: || performs logical OR operation.

column3: What is the logical NOT operator?
column9: ! negates a boolean value.
= assigns a value to a variable.
== checks if two values are equal.
!= checks if two values are not equal.

column3: What is the greater than operator?
column9: > checks if left operand is greater than right operand.

column3: What is the less than operator?
column9: < checks if left operand is less than right operand.
++ increases a variable's value by 1.
-- decreases a variable's value by 1.
#include inserts contents of a file into the source code.
#define creates macros (text substitutions).
Macro is a fragment of code given a name by #define directive.

column3: What is the difference between ++i and i++?
column9: ++i increments before using value
Global variable is accessible from any function in the file.
Local variable is accessible only within the function where declared.
Recursion is when a function calls itself directly or indirectly.
Header file contains function declarations

column3: What is the main purpose of using namespace?
column9: Namespace prevents name collisions between identifiers.

column3: What is the difference between C and C++?
column9: C++ does not
column11: C++ adds object-oriented features to C

column3: What is the first step in learning C++?
column9: Start with basic syntax
